assumption: Complex 3D architectures are necessary for high-quality continuous representations
hypothesis: Planar factorization methods (K-Planes) will demonstrate superior parameter efficiency and reconstruction quality compared to traditional MLP-based approaches (NeRF) for 2D matrix reconstruction, due to their explicit geometric bias toward planar structures inherent in 2D data
impact: Establishes 2D-specific design principles for INR architectures, moving beyond 3D-centric thinking and demonstrating architectural transferability between domains
validation_approach: Systematic evaluation with identical training protocols and statistical significance testing

assumption: Nonlinear MLP decoders are essential for expressive neural fields
hypothesis: Linear decoders with appropriate planar factorization can achieve comparable reconstruction performance to nonlinear MLP decoders while providing better computational efficiency and interpretability in 2D matrix reconstruction tasks
impact: Validates explicit geometric priors as alternatives to purely implicit representations, potentially reducing computational requirements across the field
validation_approach: Ablation studies comparing decoder architectures with controlled feature representation capacity

assumption: Positional encoding strategies optimal for 3D scenes transfer directly to 2D domains
hypothesis: 2D-specific positional encoding strategies will outperform direct adaptations of 3D-optimized encoding methods (Fourier features vs. SIREN vs. K-Planes encoding) for matrix reconstruction tasks
impact: Provides domain-specific optimization principles that could influence encoding design across INR applications
validation_approach: Comparative analysis of encoding strategies with identical architectural backbones

assumption: Architectural complexity scales necessarily with representation quality
hypothesis: Parameter efficiency improvements >2x can be achieved while maintaining or improving reconstruction quality (target: PSNR >35dB) through architectural specialization for 2D domains
impact: Demonstrates that domain-specific optimization can break traditional parameter-quality trade-offs, influencing future INR design decisions
validation_approach: Quantitative benchmarking across multiple datasets with efficiency metrics

assumption: Interpolation methods from 3D radiance fields are optimal for 2D continuous representations
hypothesis: The effect of interpolation methods (bilinear vs. learned interpolation) will show different optimization patterns in 2D compared to established 3D results, with simpler methods potentially achieving comparable results
impact: Identifies computational optimization opportunities specific to 2D INR applications
validation_approach: Controlled comparison of interpolation strategies with analysis of convergence and final performance

assumption: INRs are universally superior to explicit grid-based representations
hypothesis: Following Kim & Fridovich-Keil (2025), regularized grids with interpolation will outperform INR methods for most matrix reconstruction tasks, with INRs maintaining advantage only for matrices with underlying low-dimensional structure
impact: Challenges fundamental assumptions about INR superiority and provides practical method selection guidelines
validation_approach: Systematic evaluation following Kim & Fridovich-Keil methodology on matrix-specific datasets

assumption: Architectural innovations from 3D radiance fields cannot improve 2D matrix completion efficiency
hypothesis: Hash encoding techniques from Instant-NGP and tensor factorization from TensoRF can be successfully adapted to achieve orders of magnitude speedup in 2D matrix reconstruction while maintaining quality
impact: Demonstrates cross-domain transfer of architectural innovations, potentially revolutionizing matrix completion efficiency
validation_approach: Implementation of hash-encoded and tensor-factorized matrix completion with speed and quality benchmarking

assumption: Transfer learning is not applicable to matrix completion problems
hypothesis: STRAINER-style transfer learning approaches can achieve ≈+5dB PSNR improvement in matrix reconstruction by learning transferable features across similar matrix types (e.g., different image datasets, recommender systems)
impact: Enables few-shot matrix completion and accelerated training for new domains
validation_approach: Implementation of shared encoder architectures across matrix domains with transfer learning evaluation

assumption: Explicit and implicit representations are fundamentally incompatible
hypothesis: Hybrid approaches combining explicit grid initialization with implicit neural refinement (MetricGrids-style) will achieve superior reconstruction quality compared to pure explicit or implicit methods
impact: Opens new research direction combining benefits of both representation types
validation_approach: Development and evaluation of hybrid architectures with ablation studies isolating explicit vs implicit contributions

assumption: Hash encoding is only beneficial for 3D applications
hypothesis: Multi-resolution hash encoding adapted for 2D matrix reconstruction will achieve orders of magnitude speedup while maintaining reconstruction quality, similar to Instant-NGP results in 3D
impact: Enables practical real-time matrix completion for interactive applications
validation_approach: Implementation of hash-encoded 2D coordinate mapping with speed and quality benchmarking

assumption: Spectral analysis is not relevant to matrix completion initialization
hypothesis: WINNER-style adaptive initialization based on matrix spectral characteristics will eliminate hyperparameter search and improve convergence for matrix reconstruction tasks
impact: Simplifies matrix completion deployment and improves robustness across diverse matrix types
validation_approach: Matrix frequency analysis with adaptive noise injection based on spectral centroid

assumption: Activation function selection requires extensive hyperparameter search
hypothesis: MIRE-style dictionary learning with matrix-specific activation atoms will automatically select optimal activation patterns for different matrix characteristics without manual tuning
impact: Reduces deployment complexity and improves performance across diverse matrix reconstruction tasks
validation_approach: Development of matrix-specific activation dictionary with automatic matching

assumption: Low-rank bias in neural networks is incidental to matrix completion
hypothesis: Following Razin's rank theory, gradient-based training of INRs will naturally induce low-rank bias that aligns with matrix completion assumptions without explicit rank constraints
impact: Eliminates need for explicit nuclear norm penalties while maintaining theoretical guarantees
validation_approach: Analysis of learned representations for implicit rank structure and comparison with explicit constraints

assumption: Tensor factorization techniques are separate from neural matrix completion
hypothesis: CP-decomposition based INR architectures (following Cheng et al.) will provide more interpretable and theoretically grounded matrix reconstruction than standard MLP approaches
impact: Bridges tensor factorization theory with neural matrix completion practice
validation_approach: Implementation of CP-based tensor INR with theoretical analysis and interpretability evaluation

assumption: Domain-specific encodings are not beneficial for matrix data
hypothesis: Matrix-aware positional encoding (inspired by geographic encoding) will outperform generic Fourier features by matching coordinate systems to matrix structure characteristics
impact: Establishes domain-specific encoding as crucial for optimal matrix reconstruction performance
validation_approach: Development of matrix-specific coordinate encoding with comparative evaluation against standard approaches
